lexUnit.name: drain.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause liquid to go out of, empty from

sentence.text: After an endless pause , Roman swung away to drain the remainder of his gin and tonic , snapping the glass back on the table with a decisive click .
Relief drains the tension from her face .
Something changed in his face then , some fleeting spectre that drained the life from his eyes and left them cold and hard .
He had drained all the childlike wonder from his grown-up movies , but the grown-ups were still sitting with folded arms and stony faces , unimpressed .
When they 'd drained the last drop from the teapot Edward said , ` Run upstairs and get yourself a coat .
Great care should be taken before attempting to drain the water out of this type of system -- the boiler must be let out first .
It would drain the energy out of you . "
Spenser approves this because it does not drain English resources through having to keep a large standing army in Ireland .
As yet there is no information on whether stores regulated by RYRs can induce capacitative entry if their calcium is drained by agents such as caffeine .
It was as if the blood had been drained from her , leaving no strength , but it was n't a peaceful emptiness .
Flushing from her toes to the roots of her hair , Polly drained the last of her coffee , the mug clattering against her teeth .
It was appalling and ridiculous , and this inner battle was draining away what little strength she had left .
The Adventurers were also to ensure that all levels were driven with only a slight gradient … " just sufficient to drain out the water " .
Fry the pork in the pan until well browned , then drain off any excess fat .

In terms of short-term economic measures , the main thrust of government policy was to drain off from the economy excess money which was fuelling inflation , contributing to constant shortages and frustrating efforts at economic control .
